questions.solution:
Explanation:

Connexins form hexameric units (connexons) that align across adjacent cells to create functional gap junctions for direct intercellular communication.

  • Gap junctions are communicating junctions that allow passage of ions, sugars, nucleotides, and small molecules directly from the cytoplasm of one cell to another.
  • Each connexon is composed of six connexin subunits arranged in a ring to form a pore.
  • These junctions are critical in tissues requiring synchronized activity-e.g., cardiac myocytes, where gap junctions enable calcium flux and coordinated contraction.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Occludin (Option A): Forms part of tight junctions, which restrict paracellular movement-not gap junction communication.

Zona adherens (Option B): Refers to adherens junctions, involved in mechanical anchoring of cells via cadherins.

Zonulin (Option D): A regulator of tight junction permeability in the gut-not a structural component of cell-cell junctions.

Key Takeaway:

Connexins form gap junctions enabling intercellular exchange of small signaling molecules, essential for synchronized cellular functions.

questions.text: All of the following are intermediate filaments, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cadherins are transmembrane glycoproteins involved in cell–cell adhesion, not cytoskeletal intermediate filaments.

  • Intermediate filaments are 10 nm diameter cytoskeletal components that provide tensile strength to the cell and help maintain its structure.
  • Examples include:
    • Lamin (nuclear envelope scaffold)
    • Vimentin (mesenchymal cells)
    • Desmin (muscle cells)
  • Cadherins, on the other hand, are adhesion molecules that form anchoring junctions (adherens junctions and desmosomes) by interacting with intracellular actin filaments or intermediate filaments.
  • They play a role in maintaining epithelial integrity but are not structural filamentous proteins.

Related Important Points:

choices.text: Negative immune regulation in the treatment of cancer

questions.text: In 2018, for what contribution was the Nobel Prize given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 2018 Nobel Prize was awarded for the discovery of immune checkpoint inhibition therapy targeting CTLA-4 and PD-1.

  • James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo were awarded the Nobel Prize for their groundbreaking work on the role of immune checkpoints in cancer.
  • CTLA-4 (Cytotoxic T-Lymphocyte Antigen-4) and PD-1 (Programmed Cell Death Protein-1) are inhibitory receptors that act as immune brakes.
  • Blocking these receptors with checkpoint inhibitors leads to enhanced T-cell activity against tumor cells.
  • This discovery revolutionized cancer treatment, particularly in melanoma, lung cancer, and renal cell carcinoma.
  • Combination checkpoint blockade (CTLA-4 + PD-1) has shown superior results in treating melanoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Apoptotic pathway (Option B): Nobel awarded in earlier years (2002) for genetic regulation of organ development and programmed cell death.

CRISPR-Cas9 (Option C): Awarded in 2020 for gene-editing breakthroughs.

Circadian rhythm (Option D): Awarded in 2017 for discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian clock.

Explanation:

Integrins are transmembrane adhesion receptors that link the extracellular matrix (ECM) to the cell's cytoskeleton by binding to ECM proteins like laminin in the basal lamina.

  • Integrins primarily bind to laminin and fibronectin, key components of the ECM, enabling strong cell-matrix adhesion.
  • These interactions regulate cell migration, proliferation, differentiation, and survival.
  • On the cytoplasmic side, integrins connect to the actin cytoskeleton via linker proteins like talin, vinculin, and α-actinin.

Related Important Points:

  • Laminin: Major glycoprotein of the basal lamina; high affinity for integrins.
  • Fibronectin: Also binds integrins, but laminin is more specific to basement membrane interactions. (Option A ruled out)
  • Collagen and vitronectin are ECM proteins but less specific or indirect in integrin binding. (Option B, C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Integrins bind most prominently to laminin, a key basal lamina component, facilitating stable cell-ECM interactions.

questions.text: Tight junction consists of all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cadherin is not a component of tight junctions; it is associated with adherens junctions.

  • Tight junctions (zonula occludens) form a seal between adjacent epithelial cells to regulate paracellular permeability.
  • They are composed primarily of transmembrane proteins:
    • Claudins - essential for tight junction formation and selective permeability. (Option B)
    • Occludins - contribute to the barrier and fence functions of the tight junction. (Option A)
    • Zonula occludens (ZO-1, ZO-2) - cytoplasmic proteins that anchor claudins/occludins to the actin cytoskeleton.
  • Zonulin (a regulator protein, not a structural part) modulates tight junction permeability in certain contexts (e.g., in gut epithelium). (Option C)

Related Important Points:

  • Adherens junctions are composed of cadherins and linked to actin filaments via catenins.
  • Desmosomes use desmogleins/desmocollins (cadherin family).
  • Gap junctions are formed by connexins and allow cytoplasmic continuity.

Key Takeaway:

Cadherin is a component of adherens junctions, not tight junctions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has had increasing knee pain with movement for the past 10 years. The knee joint surfaces are eroded, and the joint spaceis narrowed. There is a loss of compressibility and lubrication of articular cartilaginous surfaces. Loss of which of the following extracellular matrix components has most likely occurred in this man?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has osteoarthritis with degenerative loss of articular hyaline cartilage, and hyaluronan is the key ECM component involved in joint lubrication and compressibility.

  • Hyaluronan (hyaluronic acid) is a high-molecular-weight glycosaminoglycan (GAG) that forms a hydrated, compressible gel in the ECM.
  • It plays a major role in maintaining the viscosity and shock-absorbing properties of synovial fluid and cartilage.
  • Loss of hyaluronan leads to decreased joint lubrication and elasticity, contributing to cartilage erosion and joint degeneration.

Related Important Points:

  • Hyaluronan is a non-sulfated GAG and does not bind to a core protein to form proteoglycans.
  • In osteoarthritis, progressive ECM degradation involves enzymes like MMPs and reduction of hyaluronan.
  • Therapeutic hyaluronic acid injections are sometimes used for symptom relief in OA.

Explanation of other options:

Elastin (Option A): Provides elasticity to tissues like arteries and skin, not joints.

Fibronectin (Option B): Functions in cell adhesion and wound healing, not joint cushioning.

Integrin (Option D): A cell surface receptor linking cytoskeleton to ECM, not responsible for compressibility.

Key Takeaway:

Hyaluronan is the primary ECM component lost in osteoarthritis, impairing joint lubrication and shock absorption.

questions.text: Which factor acts as a morphogen in embryonic development and acts as a mitogenic on hepatocytes and most epithelia ,including biliary, lung, kidney, breast, and skin.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scatter factor, also known as Hepatocyte Growth Factor (HGF), acts as both a morphogen and a mitogen:

  • HGF has potent mitogenic effects on hepatocytes and epithelial cells of the biliary tract, lungs, kidneys, breast, and skin.
  • It functions as a morphogen during embryogenesis by guiding tissue differentiation.
  • It also promotes cell motility and migration, giving rise to the name "scatter factor."
  • HGF is produced by fibroblasts, endothelial cells, and other mesenchymal-derived cells.

Related Important Points:

  • HGF acts via the c-Met receptor, a proto-oncogene product.
  • It plays a central role in organ regeneration, especially in liver repair.
  • It also enhances cell survival under stress or injury conditions.

Explanation of other options:

PDGF (Option A): Involved in wound healing and chemotaxis; not a morphogen or hepatocyte-specific mitogen.

EGF (Option B): Promotes epithelial growth but lacks morphogen function.

FGF (Option D): Promotes angiogenesis and wound healing, some are morphogens, but less specific to hepatocytes and epithelial mitogenesis compared to HGF.

Key Takeaway:

Scatter factor (HGF) uniquely combines morphogen activity with strong mitogenic effects on hepatocytes and epithelial tissues.

questions.text: Lysosomal enzymes are tagged with which residue in Golgi apparatus to direct them to the lysosome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lysosomal enzymes are tagged with mannose 6-phosphate (M6P) residues in the cis-Golgi to ensure proper targeting to lysosomes.

  • These enzymes are synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum and undergo post-translational modification in the Golgi apparatus.
  • Mannose residues on the enzymes are phosphorylated to form M6P, which acts as a molecular address tag.
  • The trans-Golgi network contains M6P receptors that bind these tagged enzymes and package them into vesicles bound for lysosomes.

Related Important Points:

  • M6P tagging is crucial for lysosomal enzyme trafficking; deficiency leads to I-cell disease (mucolipidosis II).
  • Lysosomes contain ~40 different acid hydrolases, all requiring acidic pH (~5) for optimal function.
  • Proper targeting prevents these enzymes from being secreted extracellularly.

Explanation of other options:

Glucose 6-phosphate (Option A): Involved in glycogen metabolism and glucose homeostasis, not lysosomal trafficking.

Lecithin (Option C): A phospholipid component of membranes, unrelated to protein tagging.

Phosphatidylserine (Option D): Involved in apoptotic signaling, not in lysosomal enzyme transport.

Key Takeaway:

Mannose 6-phosphate serves as the critical tag that directs newly synthesized enzymes to the lysosome.

questions.text: Thermogenin protein is mainly found in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thermogenin (Uncoupling Protein-1 or UCP1) is a specialized protein located in the inner mitochondrial membrane of brown adipose tissue.

  • It functions in non-shivering thermogenesis, especially in neonates, to protect against hypothermia.
  • Thermogenin uncouples oxidative phosphorylation by allowing protons to leak back into the mitochondrial matrix without generating ATP.
  • This dissipates the proton gradient as heat, promoting rapid substrate oxidation with reduced ATP synthesis.
  • Brown adipose tissue is rich in mitochondria and expresses high levels of thermogenin.
  • This adaptive heat-generating mechanism is vital in neonates and hibernating animals.
  • The process is stimulated by sympathetic nervous system activation.

Explanation of other options:

Golgi complex (Option A): Involved in post-translational modification and protein trafficking; no role in thermogenesis.

Nucleus (Option C): Site of DNA storage and transcription; does not contain thermogenin.

Endoplasmic reticulum (Option D): Involved in protein/lipid synthesis; thermogenin is not localized here.

Key Takeaway:

Thermogenin is a mitochondrial protein that mediates non-shivering thermogenesis in brown fat by uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation.

Explanation:

FACIT (Fibril-Associated Collagen with Interrupted Triple helices) collagens do not form fibers themselves but associate with fibrillar collagens to regulate fibril diameter and organization.

  • Type IX collagen is the prototype FACIT collagen, found predominantly in cartilage, where it binds to Type II collagen fibrils.
  • It plays a regulatory role in collagen-collagen interactions and matrix stabilization.
  • The "interrupted" triple helices allow flexibility and facilitate binding to other ECM components.
  • FACIT collagens include Type IX, XII, XIV, etc.
  • They are important in tissues requiring fibril support and stabilization, especially cartilage and tendon.
  • In contrast, fibrillar collagens (e.g., Type I, II, III) form the major structural framework.

Explanation of other options:

Type I (Option A): Major fibrillar collagen in bone, skin, and tendons-not a FACIT collagen.

Type III (Option B): Fibrillar collagen found in reticular fibers; not FACIT.

Type XI (Option D): Minor fibrillar collagen that co-assembles with Type II in cartilage-not classified as FACIT.

Key Takeaway:

Type IX collagen is a FACIT collagen involved in regulating fibril diameter and matrix interactions, particularly in cartilage.

questions.text: The Most abundant glycoprotein in the basement membrane is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laminin is the most abundant non-collagenous glycoprotein of the basement membrane, playing a critical role in cell adhesion, differentiation, migration, and survival.

  • It interacts with Type IV collagen, entactin/nidogen, and integrins to form the basement membrane scaffold.
  • Laminin promotes the attachment of epithelial cells to the underlying matrix.
  • It is essential for tissue architecture and filtration, especially in the kidney glomerular basement membrane.
  • The basement membrane is composed primarily of:
    • Type IV collagen - forms a network, not fibrils.
    • Laminin - key glycoprotein for adhesion.
    • Entactin (nidogen) - links laminin and Type IV collagen.
    • Heparan sulfate proteoglycans - e.g., perlecan.

Explanation of other options:

Rhodopsin (Option A): A photoreceptor protein found in the retina; unrelated to basement membranes.

Entactin (Option B): Also known as nidogen; supports laminin-collagen interaction but is not the most abundant.

Nidogen (Option D): Synonymous with entactin; a linker protein, not predominant in quantity.

Key Takeaway:

Laminin is the most abundant glycoprotein in the basement membrane and crucial for epithelial-matrix adhesion.

questions.text: Type 1 collagen is present in all, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type I collagen is the most abundant form of collagen and is found in tissues requiring high tensile strength such as bone, skin, tendon, dentin, fascia, and cornea.

  • It is also present in fibrocartilage, which contains both Type I and Type II collagen.
  • However, hyaline cartilage is primarily composed of Type II collagen, not Type I. (Option D ruled out)
  • Type II collagen forms fine fibrils and provides resistance to intermittent pressure in cartilage.

Key Takeaway:

Hyaline cartilage lacks Type I collagen; it is primarily composed of Type II collagen.

questions.text: The most abundant glycoprotein present in the basement membrane is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Laminin is the most abundant glycoprotein in the basement membrane, essential for its structure and function.

  • It forms a meshwork that provides adhesion sites for epithelial cells and interacts with other components such as Type IV collagen, nidogen (entactin), and heparan sulfate proteoglycans.
  • Laminin plays a key role in cell adhesion, differentiation, migration, and survival.
  • Although Type IV collagen is the main structural protein, laminin is the predominant glycoprotein.

Related Important Points:

  • Basement membrane = Type IV collagen (network-forming), laminin, nidogen, heparan sulfate (perlecan).
  • Laminin binds to integrins, facilitating cell-ECM interactions.

Explanation of other options:

Fibronectin (Option A): A glycoprotein in connective tissue ECM, not basement membrane-specific.

Collagen type IV (Option C): Most abundant protein in basement membrane, but not a glycoprotein.

Heparan sulphate (Option D): A sulfated GAG, not a glycoprotein.

Key Takeaway:

Laminin is the most abundant glycoprotein in the basement membrane and essential for epithelial anchoring.

Explanation:

10% buffered neutral formalin (BNF) is the most commonly used fixative in histopathology for routine tissue processing.

  • It is a solution of formaldehyde (4% formaldehyde gas) in water, buffered to neutral pH with phosphate.
  • It cross-links proteins, particularly lysine residues, preserving cellular and tissue architecture.
  • Used in light microscopy, including H&E staining, because it preserves tissue morphology and antigenicity well.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

10% buffered neutral formalin is the standard fixative used in routine histopathological examination.

choices.text: Only i, ii and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are the aspect(s) of any disease process?
i. Aetiology
ii. Pathogenesis
iii. Morphologic changes
iv. Clinical manifestation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The study of any disease in pathology involves understanding four core aspects:

  • Etiology: Refers to the cause of the disease (e.g., genetic or environmental factors).
  • Pathogenesis: Describes the mechanism of disease development and progression.
  • Morphologic changes: Refers to structural alterations in cells/tissues/organs.
  • Clinical manifestations: Include signs and symptoms that result from the morphologic and functional changes.

All four are essential for a comprehensive understanding of disease.

Related Important Points:

  • These four components form the foundation of pathology.
  • Understanding these helps bridge basic science with clinical medicine.

Key Takeaway:

The four pillars of pathology include etiology, pathogenesis, morphology, and clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which technique is shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immunohistochemistry (IHC) utilizes enzyme-linked antibodies to detect specific antigens in tissue sections. The brown color typically results from the diaminobenzidine (DAB) chromogen used during the detection phase.

  • DAB reacts with peroxidase to form a brown precipitate at the site of antigen-antibody binding.
  • IHC is widely used in diagnostic pathology to identify tumor markers, infectious agents, and lineage markers.
  • It is visualized under light microscopy.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

A brown stain on light microscopy typically indicates Immunohistochemistry (IHC) using diaminobenzidine (DAB).

questions.text: Which of the following stains causes brown colour to Her2neu cells of Breast Ca?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

3,3'-Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is the chromogen commonly used in immunohistochemistry (IHC) that produces a brown-colored precipitate upon reaction with horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-linked antibodies.

  • This technique is used to detect HER2/neu overexpression in breast carcinoma.
  • The brown staining pattern under light microscopy helps localize antigen expression in tissue.
  • DAB is preferred due to its stable, insoluble brown color, suitable for long-term slide storage.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:

Diaminobenzidine (DAB) is the chromogen responsible for the brown staining seen in HER2/neu-positive breast cancer cells on IHC.
